definition: A feeling of great respect mixed with wonder; to fill someone with that feeling.
examples: They stared in awe at the Northern Lights. (noun)
The vast canyon awed the hikers. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Awe = the sound you make when you’re amazed: “awww!”

definition: A sudden event that causes great damage or suffering; a disaster.
examples: The flood was a national catastrophe.
Poor planning turned the show into a catastrophe.

definition: A result or effect of an action or condition.
examples: Every choice has a consequence.
The consequence of speeding is a fine.

definition: To make someone believe something that is not true.
examples: The ad deceived customers with false claims.
He felt deceived by the rumour.

extra.memory_tip: Deceive = make someone ‘see’ the wrong thing.

definition: A death caused by an accident, war, or disease.
examples: The crash resulted in two fatalities.
Safety rules aim to reduce workplace fatalities.

definition: To create or perform without preparation, using what is available.
examples: They improvised a shelter from branches.
The actor improvised when he forgot his line.

definition: To appear as a large, unclear shape, often frighteningly; a machine for weaving cloth.
examples: Dark clouds loomed over the hills. (verb)
The old loom still worked in the mill. (noun)

definition: A temporary period of calm; to make someone or something calm or less active.
examples: There was a lull in traffic at noon. (noun)
Soft music lulled the baby to sleep. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Lull = lulla-bye leads to a lull.

definition: Calm and peaceful, with little movement or activity.
examples: The lake was placid at dawn.
She answered in a placid tone.

definition: A difficult, unpleasant, or embarrassing situation.
examples: Losing the keys put us in a predicament.
He explained his financial predicament.

definition: Something that is more important and must be dealt with first.
examples: Safety is our top priority.
Set your priorities before starting work.

definition: To strengthen or support an object, idea, or feeling.
examples: They reinforced the bridge with steel.
Praise reinforces good habits.

definition: Serious and strict; the rear part of a boat or ship.
examples: The teacher gave a stern warning. (adjective)
They stood at the stern, watching the wake. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Stern face = serious; stern of a ship = rear.

definition: Dangerous because of hidden or unpredictable hazards; not trustworthy.
examples: The icy road was treacherous.
They avoided the treacherous guide.

definition: Cautious and watchful about possible dangers or problems.
examples: Be wary of offers that sound too good.
The deer were wary of movement.
